title: 112_s1466
content: The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays is addressed in Section 1. The "Faster FOIA Act of 2011" establishes the Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays to study methods to reduce delays in processing requests to Federal agencies. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the Senate and House committees. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays consists of 12 members appointed by various government officials, with qualifications including experience as a FOIA requestor or in related fields. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will conduct a study to reduce delays in processing requests to Federal agencies under section 552 of title 5, United States Code, and examine the fee charging system. Appointments to the Commission should be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will study reducing delays in processing requests to Federal agencies under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. It will also examine the fee charging system and investigate the reasons for the increase in exemptions used by the Federal Government in fiscal year 2009. Additionally, it will assess the efforts made by Federal agencies to comply with President Obama's January 21, 2009 Presidential Memorandum on Freedom of Information Act Requests. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will study limitations on exemptions under section 552(b) of title 5, United States Code, disparities in processing FOIA requests based on political considerations, and the involvement of political appointees in the FOIA process. A report will be submitted to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will submit a report to Congress and the President with study results, including methods identified, conclusions, recommendations on fees, and legislative/administrative actions. The Archivist of the United States will provide staff and administrative support services as needed. The Archivist of the United States will pay staff and administrative expenses for the Commission from available appropriations. The Commission's expenses will not lead to future appropriations requests. Executive agencies, GAO, and CRS will provide necessary information. Commission members will serve without compensation and receive authorized travel expenses. The Administrator of General Services will pay travel expenses for Commission members while away from their regular places of business. Expenses paid under this subsection will not result in additional appropriations requests. All Commission meetings will be open to the public, except for specific matters that may be closed to the public. The Commission allows interested persons to participate in open meetings by presenting oral or written statements. The Commission may administer oaths to individuals appearing before it. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report.
